The Interior Plateau ( Fennsík ) Behind the Spine, a vast elevated plateau stretches toward the northern ice. Characteristics: - Elevation: 1,500-2,000m above sea level - Climate: Cold, dry, windy - Vegetation: Hardy tundra grasses, black lichen, scattered dwarf trees - Population: Sparse—nomadic herders, mining settlements, Warden outposts - Pattern Residue: High concentration (ancient battlefield sites, unexcavated) The River Valleys Major rivers cut through the Spine from the interior, creating the primary population centers. The Five Rivers : 1. The Gold ( Aranyi ): Largest river, drains to the southeast coast. The capital region. 2. The Iron ( Vasalj ): Northern river, flows to the Narrow Sea. Industrial heartland. 3. The Silent ( Csendi ): Flows north, disappears under the ice cap. Sacred to Ancestor Speakers. 4. The Broken ( Törötti ): Western river, fragmented into multiple channels. Difficult to navigate. 5. The Vein ( Véna ): Southern river, reddish sediment. Flesh Shaper territory—the sediment is mineral, not blood, but the association stuck. The Southern Coast The concave inner coast facing the Middle Waters. Characteristics: - Climate: Mildest on the continent (warm current arrival) - Terrain: Rolling hills, river deltas, natural harbors - Population: Dense—major cities, agricultural land, trade ports - Loom Coverage: Maximum—the Great Node is here The Northern Edge Where the continent meets the ice cap. Characteristics: - Climate: Extreme—permanent ice within 100km - Terrain: Glacial, unstable, constantly shifting - Population: Minimal—extraction outposts, Warden stations, exiles - Köd Effects: Partial bleed zone during the fifth season
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Heartlands contain multiple political entities, but shared characteristics: - Orthodox faith dominant - Loom integration in governance - Recognition of the Great Node's authority (in religious matters at minimum) - Interconnected through the river valley trade networks Specific nations/kingdoms to be developed separately.
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: The "missing piece" of the original continent, now fragmented into one large island-continent and hundreds of smaller islands. The western coast clearly shows where it once connected to the Heartlands. Main Island : Roughly 1,500 km north-south, 600 km east-west Island Chains : Extending another 1,000 km eastward in clusters
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Matching Coast The western edge of the main island—steep cliffs, deep fjords, a mirror of the Heartlands' eastern ragged coast. Sailors navigating the Narrow Sea see both coasts and understand they're traveling through a wound. The Interior Highlands The main island's interior is mountainous—a continuation of the Spine, now separated. Characteristics: - Peaks lower than the Spine (erosion, or the separation lowered them) - Heavy precipitation (maritime climate) - Dense, dark forests in the valleys (black-barked conifers) - Fast rivers with short courses to the sea The Fracture Zone The eastern portion of the main island and the inner island chains show evidence of additional breaking—smaller rifts, sea-filled valleys, unstable geology. Theories: - Secondary breaks after the main separation - Ongoing geological instability - The pattern continues to crack - Elsewhere influence weakening material reality The Island Chains Hundreds of islands extending eastward: The Near Chains : Close to the main island, connected by sea ice during Csend. Large islands with permanent populations, small islands used seasonally. The Middle Chains : Further out, less connected. Independent communities, sometimes isolated for entire winters. Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions. The Far Chains : Scattered islands approaching the Far Water. Sparse population, expedition staging points, pirate havens.
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Shattered Reaches are defined by the sea: - Every settlement is coastal or river-accessible - Naval power determines political influence - Fishing and sea-hunting are primary food sources - Shipbuilding is the prestige industry - Sea ice creates seasonal connectivity (Csend connects islands; Olvadás isolates them)
docs.title: Maritime Character

docs.text: Fragmented by design: - No continental-scale political unity - City-states control mainland harbors - Island kingdoms vary in size from single-island to chain-spanning - Merchant leagues provide economic coherence across political divisions - The Orthodox church is present but not dominant
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: An archipelago of volcanic islands straddling the equatorial band. The warmest region on Hálcova—the only place that never freezes. The Great Island : Central caldera island, roughly 200 km diameter Major Islands : 20-30 islands of significant size (50+ km) Minor Islands : Hundreds of smaller islands, atolls, and reef formations
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Caldera ( The Eye ) The Great Island is the rim and interior of a dormant supervolcano. The caldera itself is partially flooded, creating a protected inner harbor of extraordinary value. Characteristics: - Caldera diameter: ~50 km - Rim elevation: 500-1,500m above sea level - Inner harbor: Deep, protected, warm - Geothermal activity: Hot springs, steam vents, warm ground - Köd protection: The caldera experiences almost no Elsewhere effects The Protection Mystery : Why is the caldera protected during Köd? Theories: - Geothermal energy disrupts the bleed - Ancient warding built into the volcanic structure - High life density anchors reality - Something in the caldera that Elsewhere avoids - Combination of factors The truth may involve ancient engineering—the caldera shows signs of modification that don't match natural formation. The Reef Systems Cold-adapted reef analogues (not coral—something else) surround many islands. Characteristics: - Built by colonial organisms adapted to cold water - Create protected lagoons and channels - Rich fishing grounds - Navigation hazards for unfamiliar sailors - Possible Pattern Residue interaction (the organisms may process it somehow) The Thermal Vents Underwater volcanic vents heat surrounding waters. Where these occur: - Water temperature is significantly higher - Unique ecosystems develop - Fog banks form (warm water meeting cold air) - Strategic value for winter fishing grounds
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: Why the Middle Waters stay warm: Latitude : Equatorial position receives maximum Sárgvas energy Volcanic heat : Geothermal contribution to ground and water temperature Ocean currents : Warm water pools here rather than flowing away quickly Köd protection : Less Pattern Residue precipitation during the strange season Unknown factor : The caldera's protection extends partially to surrounding islands
docs.title: Climate Advantage

docs.text: The most contested territory on Hálcova: - Every major power wants presence here - Colonial holdings, trading posts, military bases from multiple regions - Native island cultures caught between imperial interests - Colony Cults have significant influence (warm, wet conditions favor fungi) - Religious diversity—Orthodoxy present but not dominant
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: A continental fragment in the southern hemisphere, defined by extreme volcanic activity. Smaller than the Heartlands but geologically intense. Dimensions : Roughly 1,200 km north-south, 800 km east-west Coastline : Irregular, with many peninsulas and deep bays
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Fire Range ( Tűzlánc ) An active volcanic mountain chain running the length of the landmass. Characteristics: - 20+ active volcanoes - Continuous geothermal activity (hot springs, geysers, fumaroles) - Lava flows reshape geography on human timescales - Ash falls fertilize surrounding valleys - Toxic gas zones in low-lying areas The Thermal Valleys Protected valleys between volcanic ridges where geothermal heat creates habitable conditions. Characteristics: - Warm year-round (geothermal, not solar) - Lush vegetation (by Hálcova standards) - Dense population concentration - Natural hot water for bathing, cleaning, industrial processes - Some valleys toxic or unstable (constant monitoring required) The Steam Fields Where glaciers meet geothermal zones. Characteristics: - Constant steam and fog - Unstable footing (ice over warm ground) - Flash floods when ice dams break - Bizarre ice formations (frozen steam, thermal-sculpted glaciers) - Disorienting travel conditions The Sulfur Flats Lowland areas where volcanic gases concentrate. Characteristics: - Yellow-crusted ground (sulfur deposits) - Toxic air at ground level - Uninhabitable without protection - Valuable mineral extraction (sulfur, other volcanic minerals) - Worked by protected crews or homunculi
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Vent Lands don't need Pattern Residue for heat: - Geothermal energy provides heating, cooking, industrial power - Independence from the Residue trade network - Wealth from unique resources (volcanic minerals, geothermal-forged metals) - Political independence from Orthodox/Loom institutional pressure - Fleshwright traditions developed here (blood doesn't freeze; more experimentation possible)
docs.title: Economic Advantage

docs.text: Unified by geography rather than conquest: - Thermal valleys function as semi-independent city-states - Volcanic activity forces cooperation (warning systems, refugee support) - Trade federation rather than empire - Orthodoxy present but weaker (they need the Vent Lands more than reverse) - Fleshwright guilds have unusual legal status and power
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: The most distant inhabited continent, in the southern hemisphere. Large, relatively flat, and cold. Dimensions : Roughly 2,000 km east-west, 1,500 km north-south Coastline : Long and exposed, few natural harbors
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Shelf Proper The continent is a vast, low-elevation landmass—a continental shelf that barely rises above sea level in many areas. Characteristics: - Elevation: 0-500m over most of the landmass - Terrain: Flat to gently rolling - Drainage: Poor—marshes, bogs, seasonal lakes - Permafrost: Underlies most of the interior The Southern Ice Edge The continent's southern coast merges into the southern ice cap. Characteristics: - No clear boundary between land and ice - Glaciers extend from the cap across coastal regions - Ice cliffs along some stretches - Full Köd bleed zone The Mineral Ranges Low mountain ranges in the continental interior. Characteristics: - Rich ore deposits (iron, copper, rare metals) - Difficult extraction (permafrost, short work season) - Mining settlements operate seasonally or with heavy Residue-burning for heat - Tensions between extraction interests and indigenous populations The Tundra Most of the continental interior. Characteristics: - Black and purple vegetation mat (tundra grasses, lichens) - Migrating herd animals - Nomadic populations following herds - Long winters, brief intense summers - Less Loom coverage than any other inhabited region
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Far Shelf is the edge of the known world: - Last region to be contacted/colonized - Still incompletely mapped in the interior - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Threadist movements began here (distance from Orthodox center) - Hollow Saints operate more openly - Warden Order presence thin and stretched
docs.title: Frontier Character

docs.text: Fragmented and contested: - Coastal trading posts controlled by distant powers - Interior effectively independent (hard to project power into tundra) - Indigenous confederacies resist external control - Colonial tensions with Heartlands interests - Religious heterodoxy tolerated by necessity
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : - Width: 200-400 km at various points - Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves - Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north - Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) - Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : - Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás - Fog banks where water temperatures differ - Tidal races in narrow passages - Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : - Controls trade between two major regions - Historical site of naval conflicts - Chokepoints fortified on both sides - Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics
docs.title: The Narrow Sea

docs.text: Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : - Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places - Depth: Deep ocean basins - Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) - Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : - Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) - Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) - Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) - The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed)
docs.title: The Central Ocean

docs.text: Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : - Width: 300-500 km - Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) - Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources - Ice: Never freezes - Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : - Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) - Dense fog (warm water, cold air) - Crowded shipping lanes - Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation)
docs.title: The Vent Strait

docs.text: Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : - Width: 3,000+ km at minimum - Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches - Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice - Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through - Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : - Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) - Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) - Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) - Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) - Isolation (rescue is unlikely)
docs.title: The Far Water

docs.text: Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : - Route: Curves north through near-polar waters - Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route - Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road - Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : - Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing - Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage - Operates only during Csend (narrow window) - Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season - Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring)
docs.title: The Bitter Crossing

docs.text: Extent : Everything north of approximately 70° latitude equivalent Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (3-4 km thick in center) - No permanent human habitation in deep polar zone - Transition zone (ice edge to permanent ice) is seasonally accessible - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season What's There : - Ice - Concentrated Pattern Residue (ancient, unharvested) - Ruins under the ice (confirmed by expeditions) - Creatures adapted to extreme cold (rare, dangerous) - Something else (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Northern Cap

docs.text: Extent : Everything south of approximately 65° latitude equivalent (extends further north due to continental anchoring by the Far Shelf) Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (thinner than northern, 1-2 km) - Merges with the Far Shelf's southern coast - Slightly more accessible (land connection) - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season - Different character from the northern cap (see: Polar Mystery) What's There : - Ice - The Shelf's southern glaciers - Mineral deposits (inaccessible) - Something different from the north (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Southern Cap

docs.text: The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound - This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova - The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection - The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage - Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison - Something is contained here - The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) - The cold is more engineered than natural - Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live - Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : - Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere - Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment - Very few people know both truths - The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?)
docs.title: The Polar Mystery
Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop

docs.text: Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources.
docs.title: The System

docs.text: The Middle Flow : - Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) - Surface flow moves north and south toward poles - Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures - Provides moisture for precipitation - Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts.
docs.title: Surface Currents (Warm)

docs.text: The Return Flow : - Surface water cools as it moves poleward - Cold water sinks at high latitudes - Deep current returns toward equator - Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate.
docs.title: Deep Currents (Cold)

docs.text: Láng (Summer) : - Surface currents strongest (maximum heating) - Ice retreat reveals more ocean surface - Trade routes fully open - Fish populations migrate with warm water Csend (Winter) : - Surface currents weakest - Ice formation begins at high latitudes - Currents may shift as ice blocks normal flows - Some routes become impassable Olvadás (Thaw) : - Meltwater influx disrupts currents - Unpredictable flows - Dangerous for shipping (currents don't follow normal patterns) - Rich nutrient release from melting ice Further documentation needed on: Specific coastline details, exact current speeds and patterns, submarine geology, maritime culture and technology
docs.title: Seasonal Variations

docs.text: Hálcova: Lunar System and Celestial Mechanics Overview Hálcova's five moons are not natural. The orbital mechanics are too perfect, the resonances too stable. Someone—or something—arranged them. This document covers what's observable and measurable, and addresses the mystery of their origin. The Five Moons: Detailed Parameters Lélek (The Soul Moon) Pronunciation : LAY-lek Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~1,200 km (about 1/3 Luna) - Surface: Pale gold/amber coloration, cratered - Albedo: High (reflects Sárgvas light efficiently) - Composition: Rocky, possibly metalite-rich (explains color) Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 30 local days - Distance: ~180,000 km (closer than Luna) - Inclination: 5° to Hálcova's equator - Eccentricity: 0.02 (nearly circular) Appearance from Surface : - Largest moon in the sky - Obvious phases, easily tracked - Pale gold color, sometimes amber during horizon view - Surface features visible to naked eye Associations : - Léilcrù circle (Soul/Core) - Core Binding practice - Orthodox religious significance (The Weaver's first finger) Hús (The Flesh Moon) Pronunciation : HOOSH Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~600 km - Surface: Iron-oxide rich, distinctly reddish - Albedo: Moderate - Composition: Dense, iron-heavy Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 18 local days - Distance: ~120,000 km - Inclination: 8° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.03 Appearance from Surface : - Medium-sized disc - Distinctly red/rust colored - Moves noticeably faster across sky than Lélek - Phases cycle quickly Associations : - Húslaimh circle (Flesh/Body) - Flesh Shaping practice - Blood, meat, physical existence - Considered unlucky to perform surgery when Hús is dark Kötel (The Binding Moon) Pronunciation : KUH-tel Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~700 km - Surface: Dark grey, low reflectivity - Albedo: Low (hard to see) - Composition: Carbon-rich rock, possibly ancient Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 45 local days - Distance: ~250,000 km - Inclination: 3° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.01 (most circular) Appearance from Surface : - Medium-sized but dim - Easy to lose track of (dark surface) - "The hidden moon"—often overlooked - Best visible during its rare bright phases Associations : - Cóitcai circle (Binding/Connection) - Pact Summoning - Hidden contracts, secrets - "Under Kötel" means "in secret" in common speech Vég (The Death Moon) Pronunciation : VAYG Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~300 km - Surface: Bright white/grey, high reflectivity - Albedo: Very high (ice surface?) - Composition: Unknown—spectral analysis inconsistent Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 12 local days - Distance: ~80,000 km (closest moon) - Inclination: 12° to equator (highest) - Eccentricity: 0.05 (most elliptical) Appearance from Surface : - Small but bright - Moves rapidly across sky - Almost star-like at distance, but tracking reveals motion - Inclined orbit means it sometimes appears far from other moons Associations : - Hálmaht circle (Death/End) - Colony Summoning - Endings, transitions, death - Fast movement associated with "life is brief" Fonál (The Fate Moon) Pronunciation : FOH-nahl Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~200 km - Surface: Grey-white, unremarkable - Albedo: Moderate - Composition: Unknown—too distant for clear analysis Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 60 local days - Distance: ~350,000 km (most distant) - Inclination: 2° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.02 Appearance from Surface : - Very small, often mistaken for bright star - Slow-moving, easy to lose - Requires knowledge to track - "The distant thread" Associations : - Sórscad circle (Fate/Path) - Fate Threading - Long-term destiny, the far view - Astrologers and Loom-Keepers track it carefully Orbital Resonances The Artificial Pattern The five moons' orbital periods form near-perfect ratios: Ratio Moons Period Relationship 2:3 Vég : Hús 12 : 18 days 2:3 Hús : Lélek 18 : 30 (actually 27, but close) 3:2 Lélek : Kötel 30 : 45 days 3:4 Kötel : Fonál 45 : 60 days These resonances keep the system stable. Without them, gravitational interactions would have destabilized the orbits over millions of years. The Implication : This configuration is not random. Either: 1. The moons were placed deliberately 2. The moons were adjusted into resonance 3. Something maintains the resonance actively Natural vs. Engineered Arguments for Natural Formation : - Resonance locks can form naturally (see Jupiter's moons) - Given enough time, systems find stable configurations - No direct evidence of construction Arguments for Engineering : - Five moons is unusual (most systems have 0-2 large moons) - The color/composition variety suggests different origins - Perfect resonance ratios are improbably clean - Cultural significance (five moons = five circles = five arts) suggests someone designed for meaning - Vég's spectral inconsistency suggests it's not normal rock/ice Prevailing Theory (among those who study such things): The moons existed but were adjusted—moved into their current orbits by some ancient civilization or the Elsewhere itself. The purpose: unknown. The timing: before recorded history. Alignment Events Calculation Finding when moons align requires calculating the Least Common Multiple of orbital periods: - LCM(12, 18, 30, 45, 60) = 180 days Full five-moon alignment : Every 180 local days (~twice per year) Alignment Types The Hand Closes (All Five Aligned) - Occurs every 180 days - All five moons in same region of sky - Major religious/cultural event - The Loom's accuracy reportedly spikes - Some magical operations enhanced - Some forbidden during this time The Three Fingers (Lélek + Hús + Kötel) - More frequent - Associated with binding magic generally - "Good" time for contracts and pacts The Death Pair (Vég + Fonál) - Small moons together - Associated with endings - Funeral timing often matches this alignment Opposition Alignments - When moons are on opposite sides of Hálcova - Creates complex tidal effects - Associated with conflict, division - "Moons at war" in common speech The Köd Alignment During the fifth season, moon positions have additional significance: Full alignment during Köd: Extremely rare, deeply feared Fonál invisible during Köd: "Fate hidden"—normal, expected Lélek dark during Köd: Considered dangerous (soul unprotected) Tidal Effects Basic Mechanics Five moons create overlapping tidal forces: - Each moon pulls water toward it - Multiple moons can reinforce or cancel - Tidal patterns are complex but predictable Tidal Categories Spring Tides (Moons Aligned) - Maximum tidal range - Dangerous for coastal areas - Opens/closes certain sea routes - Exposes tidal flats, submerges land bridges Neap Tides (Moons Opposed) - Minimum tidal range - Calmer waters - Different navigation challenges - Some harbors become inaccessible Great Tides (Five-Moon Alignment) - Extreme tidal range - Flooding in vulnerable areas - Sea ice behavior disrupted - Scheduled events (prepared for in advance) - Harvesting opportunities (what the tide exposes) Regional Tidal Variation Region Tidal Intensity Notes Narrow Sea Moderate Channeled between continents Shattered Reaches Extreme Complex coastlines amplify Middle Waters Moderate Open ocean buffering Vent Strait Low-Moderate Warm water density difference Far Shelf Moderate Long, exposed coastline Polar Seas Low Ice dampens tidal movement Tidal Timing and Culture Navigation : - Tide tables are essential documents - Skilled navigators memorize patterns - Errors kill ships and crews Architecture : - Coastal cities built to tidal range - Flooding expected, prepared for - Tide-gates on harbors and districts Ritual : - Religious ceremonies timed to tides - "Tide-naming" for children born during specific tides - Marriage timing considers tidal auspices Eclipse Patterns Solar Eclipses Lélek Solar Eclipse : - Only moon large enough for full solar eclipse - Occurs when Lélek crosses Sárgvas during new moon - Not every cycle (orbital inclination) - Duration: Up to 6 minutes of totality - Frequency: 1-2 per year (partial more common) Smaller Moon Transits : - Hús, Kötel, Vég, Fonál all transit Sárgvas - Visible as black dots crossing solar disc - Scientifically interesting, culturally minor - Transit timing used for orbital calculations Lunar Eclipses Hálcova's Shadow : - All moons pass through Hálcova's shadow periodically - Duration varies by moon size and distance - Moons turn dark red during eclipse (Sárgvas light through atmosphere) Eclipse Frequency by Moon : | Moon | Full Eclipse/Year | Notes | |------|-------------------|-------| | Lélek | 2-3 | Most dramatic | | Hús | 4-5 | Fast, brief | | Kötel | 1-2 | Hard to see (already dim) | | Vég | 6-8 | Frequent due to inclined orbit | | Fonál | 1 | Rare, distant | Moon-Moon Occultations Occasionally, one moon passes in front of another from Hálcova's perspective: Common Occultations : - Lélek occulting others: Most visible (large, bright covering small) - Vég occulting Fonál: Both small and dim, hard to observe - Any inner moon occulting any outer moon: Geometrically possible Cultural Significance : Each combination has interpreted meaning: - Lélek over Hús: "Soul masters flesh" - Hús over Lélek: "Flesh obscures soul" (rare, requires specific geometry) - Vég over any moon: "Death touches [that domain]" - Kötel occulting: "Contracts hidden" The Arrangement Question What We Know Five moons in stable resonance is improbable naturally The moons have different compositions (different origins?) Orbital periods create meaningful ratios Cultural/magical significance of five is pervasive No records of arrangement exist (predates history) Theories The Weaver's Design (Orthodox) - The divine pattern-maker arranged the moons as part of fate's infrastructure - They serve The Loom's function - Their arrangement proves intelligent design - Questioning further is impious The Ancient Engineers (Scholarly) - A pre-human or early human civilization moved the moons - Perhaps the same civilization that built the polar structures - The technology is lost, but the result persists - Understanding how could unlock power The Elsewhere Anchor (Heterodox) - The moons are anchor points for Elsewhere connection - They define the boundaries of the bleed - Their arrangement determines where and when the Elsewhere can manifest - The five factions may correspond to the five moons The Prison Bars (Hollow Saint) - The moons are part of the cage of fate - They enforce the Sórscad system - Disrupting them might free humanity from pattern - (Nobody has proposed a method) The Natural Improbability (Fleshwright) - Improbable doesn't mean impossible - Given the universe's age, unlikely configurations happen somewhere - Attributing design is anthropocentric bias - The cultural significance was imposed after, not built in Observable Evidence Supporting Artificial Arrangement : - Vég's spectral inconsistency (not normal material) - Perfect resonance ratios - Correlation between moon positions and magical phenomena - The Elsewhere bleed's relationship to lunar cycles Against : - No construction evidence on moon surfaces (from telescopes) - No historical records despite extensive ancient archives - If arrangement technology existed, where is it? The Working Answer For practical purposes, most people accept: - The moons are where they are - They affect tides, magic, and fate - Whether designed or natural, they're part of reality - Understanding the how might matter; understanding the why probably doesn't Calendar and Timekeeping The Lunar Calendar Various cultures use different moon-based calendars: Lélek Months : - 30-day months (Lélek's period) - 11.67 months per year - Practical but doesn't divide evenly Vég Weeks : - 12-day "weeks" (Vég's period) - 29.22 weeks per year - Used in some trading cultures The Five-Moon Year : - Track all five moons' cycles - Complex but comprehensive - Used by Loom-Keepers and astrologers - Average person can't maintain Standard Timekeeping Most cultures have settled on: - 36-hour day divided into segments (varies by culture) - Year of 350-351 days (with intercalary adjustments) - Five seasons as primary year division - Lunar positions noted for special occasions Further documentation needed on: Detailed tide tables by region, eclipse prediction methods, calendar conversion between systems, moon surface mapping, tidal creature behavior

docs.text: Pronunciation : KUH-tel Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~700 km - Surface: Dark grey, low reflectivity - Albedo: Low (hard to see) - Composition: Carbon-rich rock, possibly ancient Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 45 local days - Distance: ~250,000 km - Inclination: 3° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.01 (most circular) Appearance from Surface : - Medium-sized but dim - Easy to lose track of (dark surface) - "The hidden moon"—often overlooked - Best visible during its rare bright phases Associations : - Cóitcai circle (Binding/Connection) - Pact Summoning - Hidden contracts, secrets - "Under Kötel" means "in secret" in common speech
docs.title: Kötel (The Binding Moon)

docs.text: Pronunciation : VAYG Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~300 km - Surface: Bright white/grey, high reflectivity - Albedo: Very high (ice surface?) - Composition: Unknown—spectral analysis inconsistent Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 12 local days - Distance: ~80,000 km (closest moon) - Inclination: 12° to equator (highest) - Eccentricity: 0.05 (most elliptical) Appearance from Surface : - Small but bright - Moves rapidly across sky - Almost star-like at distance, but tracking reveals motion - Inclined orbit means it sometimes appears far from other moons Associations : - Hálmaht circle (Death/End) - Colony Summoning - Endings, transitions, death - Fast movement associated with "life is brief"
docs.title: Vég (The Death Moon)

docs.text: Pronunciation : FOH-nahl Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~200 km - Surface: Grey-white, unremarkable - Albedo: Moderate - Composition: Unknown—too distant for clear analysis Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 60 local days - Distance: ~350,000 km (most distant) - Inclination: 2° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.02 Appearance from Surface : - Very small, often mistaken for bright star - Slow-moving, easy to lose - Requires knowledge to track - "The distant thread" Associations : - Sórscad circle (Fate/Path) - Fate Threading - Long-term destiny, the far view - Astrologers and Loom-Keepers track it carefully
docs.title: Fonál (The Fate Moon)

docs.text: The five moons' orbital periods form near-perfect ratios: Ratio Moons Period Relationship 2:3 Vég : Hús 12 : 18 days 2:3 Hús : Lélek 18 : 30 (actually 27, but close) 3:2 Lélek : Kötel 30 : 45 days 3:4 Kötel : Fonál 45 : 60 days These resonances keep the system stable. Without them, gravitational interactions would have destabilized the orbits over millions of years. The Implication : This configuration is not random. Either: 1. The moons were placed deliberately 2. The moons were adjusted into resonance 3. Something maintains the resonance actively
docs.title: The Artificial Pattern

docs.text: Arguments for Natural Formation : - Resonance locks can form naturally (see Jupiter's moons) - Given enough time, systems find stable configurations - No direct evidence of construction Arguments for Engineering : - Five moons is unusual (most systems have 0-2 large moons) - The color/composition variety suggests different origins - Perfect resonance ratios are improbably clean - Cultural significance (five moons = five circles = five arts) suggests someone designed for meaning - Vég's spectral inconsistency suggests it's not normal rock/ice Prevailing Theory (among those who study such things): The moons existed but were adjusted—moved into their current orbits by some ancient civilization or the Elsewhere itself. The purpose: unknown. The timing: before recorded history.
docs.title: Natural vs. Engineered

docs.text: Finding when moons align requires calculating the Least Common Multiple of orbital periods: - LCM(12, 18, 30, 45, 60) = 180 days Full five-moon alignment : Every 180 local days (~twice per year)
docs.title: Calculation

docs.text: The Hand Closes (All Five Aligned) - Occurs every 180 days - All five moons in same region of sky - Major religious/cultural event - The Loom's accuracy reportedly spikes - Some magical operations enhanced - Some forbidden during this time The Three Fingers (Lélek + Hús + Kötel) - More frequent - Associated with binding magic generally - "Good" time for contracts and pacts The Death Pair (Vég + Fonál) - Small moons together - Associated with endings - Funeral timing often matches this alignment Opposition Alignments - When moons are on opposite sides of Hálcova - Creates complex tidal effects - Associated with conflict, division - "Moons at war" in common speech
docs.title: Alignment Types

docs.text: During the fifth season, moon positions have additional significance: Full alignment during Köd: Extremely rare, deeply feared Fonál invisible during Köd: "Fate hidden"—normal, expected Lélek dark during Köd: Considered dangerous (soul unprotected)
docs.title: The Köd Alignment

docs.text: Five moons create overlapping tidal forces: - Each moon pulls water toward it - Multiple moons can reinforce or cancel - Tidal patterns are complex but predictable
docs.title: Basic Mechanics

docs.text: Spring Tides (Moons Aligned) - Maximum tidal range - Dangerous for coastal areas - Opens/closes certain sea routes - Exposes tidal flats, submerges land bridges Neap Tides (Moons Opposed) - Minimum tidal range - Calmer waters - Different navigation challenges - Some harbors become inaccessible Great Tides (Five-Moon Alignment) - Extreme tidal range - Flooding in vulnerable areas - Sea ice behavior disrupted - Scheduled events (prepared for in advance) - Harvesting opportunities (what the tide exposes)
docs.title: Tidal Categories

docs.title: Regional Tidal Variation

docs.text: Navigation : - Tide tables are essential documents - Skilled navigators memorize patterns - Errors kill ships and crews Architecture : - Coastal cities built to tidal range - Flooding expected, prepared for - Tide-gates on harbors and districts Ritual : - Religious ceremonies timed to tides - "Tide-naming" for children born during specific tides - Marriage timing considers tidal auspices
docs.title: Tidal Timing and Culture

docs.text: Lélek Solar Eclipse : - Only moon large enough for full solar eclipse - Occurs when Lélek crosses Sárgvas during new moon - Not every cycle (orbital inclination) - Duration: Up to 6 minutes of totality - Frequency: 1-2 per year (partial more common) Smaller Moon Transits : - Hús, Kötel, Vég, Fonál all transit Sárgvas - Visible as black dots crossing solar disc - Scientifically interesting, culturally minor - Transit timing used for orbital calculations
docs.title: Solar Eclipses

docs.text: Hálcova's Shadow : - All moons pass through Hálcova's shadow periodically - Duration varies by moon size and distance - Moons turn dark red during eclipse (Sárgvas light through atmosphere) Eclipse Frequency by Moon : | Moon | Full Eclipse/Year | Notes | |------|-------------------|-------| | Lélek | 2-3 | Most dramatic | | Hús | 4-5 | Fast, brief | | Kötel | 1-2 | Hard to see (already dim) | | Vég | 6-8 | Frequent due to inclined orbit | | Fonál | 1 | Rare, distant |
docs.title: Lunar Eclipses

docs.text: Occasionally, one moon passes in front of another from Hálcova's perspective: Common Occultations : - Lélek occulting others: Most visible (large, bright covering small) - Vég occulting Fonál: Both small and dim, hard to observe - Any inner moon occulting any outer moon: Geometrically possible Cultural Significance : Each combination has interpreted meaning: - Lélek over Hús: "Soul masters flesh" - Hús over Lélek: "Flesh obscures soul" (rare, requires specific geometry) - Vég over any moon: "Death touches [that domain]" - Kötel occulting: "Contracts hidden"
docs.title: Moon-Moon Occultations

docs.text: Five moons in stable resonance is improbable naturally The moons have different compositions (different origins?) Orbital periods create meaningful ratios Cultural/magical significance of five is pervasive No records of arrangement exist (predates history)
docs.title: What We Know

docs.text: The Weaver's Design (Orthodox) - The divine pattern-maker arranged the moons as part of fate's infrastructure - They serve The Loom's function - Their arrangement proves intelligent design - Questioning further is impious The Ancient Engineers (Scholarly) - A pre-human or early human civilization moved the moons - Perhaps the same civilization that built the polar structures - The technology is lost, but the result persists - Understanding how could unlock power The Elsewhere Anchor (Heterodox) - The moons are anchor points for Elsewhere connection - They define the boundaries of the bleed - Their arrangement determines where and when the Elsewhere can manifest - The five factions may correspond to the five moons The Prison Bars (Hollow Saint) - The moons are part of the cage of fate - They enforce the Sórscad system - Disrupting them might free humanity from pattern - (Nobody has proposed a method) The Natural Improbability (Fleshwright) - Improbable doesn't mean impossible - Given the universe's age, unlikely configurations happen somewhere - Attributing design is anthropocentric bias - The cultural significance was imposed after, not built in
docs.title: Theories

docs.text: Supporting Artificial Arrangement : - Vég's spectral inconsistency (not normal material) - Perfect resonance ratios - Correlation between moon positions and magical phenomena - The Elsewhere bleed's relationship to lunar cycles Against : - No construction evidence on moon surfaces (from telescopes) - No historical records despite extensive ancient archives - If arrangement technology existed, where is it?
docs.title: Observable Evidence

docs.text: For practical purposes, most people accept: - The moons are where they are - They affect tides, magic, and fate - Whether designed or natural, they're part of reality - Understanding the how might matter; understanding the why probably doesn't
docs.title: The Working Answer

docs.text: Various cultures use different moon-based calendars: Lélek Months : - 30-day months (Lélek's period) - 11.67 months per year - Practical but doesn't divide evenly Vég Weeks : - 12-day "weeks" (Vég's period) - 29.22 weeks per year - Used in some trading cultures The Five-Moon Year : - Track all five moons' cycles - Complex but comprehensive - Used by Loom-Keepers and astrologers - Average person can't maintain
docs.title: The Lunar Calendar

docs.text: Most cultures have settled on: - 36-hour day divided into segments (varies by culture) - Year of 350-351 days (with intercalary adjustments) - Five seasons as primary year division - Lunar positions noted for special occasions Further documentation needed on: Detailed tide tables by region, eclipse prediction methods, calendar conversion between systems, moon surface mapping, tidal creature behavior

Five moons create overlapping tidal cycles - "Great Tides" occur when multiple moons align (predictable but rare) - Extreme tidal ranges during alignment affect: - Coastal construction and habitation - Sea ice formation and breakup - Marine creature behavior - Navigation and port schedules Cultural Significance : - Each moon associated with a Sórscad circle and magical practice - Lunar conjunctions considered ominous or auspicious depending on combination - Timekeeping uses lunar cycles alongside solar year - Religious festivals tied to specific moon phases and alignments Auroral Phenomena Why Auroras Are Extreme Contributing Factors : - Weaker magnetic field (slower rotation = weaker dynamo) - Five moons (potential magnetic field interactions) - K-star solar wind (different particle composition) - Pattern Residue atmospheric concentration Characteristics : - More frequent (weaker magnetic shielding) - Visible at lower latitudes (larger auroral oval) - Different color palette (more reds, purples from K-star spectrum) - Correlated with moon positions - Correlated with Pattern Residue concentration The Aurora-Magic Connection Observed Correlations : - High aurora activity = high Residue concentration - The Loom is more accurate during aurora events - Certain magical operations more effective - Wardens more sensitive to deviation detection - Echoes more active and coherent Possible Explanations : - Residue particles interact with solar wind - The magnetic field channels both phenomena - Auroras are visible manifestation of Residue energy state - Unknown causal relationship Climate System Why Hálcova Is Cold Multiple Contributing Factors : Distance from Sárgvas : Orbits at distance producing ice-world baseline Dimmer star : K-type provides less energy than G-type at same distance Atmospheric composition : Less greenhouse effect than Earth Pattern Residue : Ambient Residue absorbs thermal energy (see below) Temperature Ranges Zone Láng (Summer) Csend (Winter) Middle Waters (warmest) +10°C to +20°C +5°C to +10°C Temperate coasts +5°C to +15°C -15°C to -5°C Continental interior 0°C to +10°C -30°C to -15°C Transition zones -5°C to +5°C -40°C to -25°C Polar edges -15°C to -5°C -60°C to -40°C Deep polar -30°C to -20°C Below -70°C Pattern Residue and Temperature The Mechanism : Pattern Residue in its "charged" state absorbs thermal energy from the environment. It is thermodynamically active—pulling heat into itself. The Feedback Loop : 1. Death releases Pattern Residue 2. Residue absorbs heat from environment 3. Environment cools 4. Cold contributes to more death 5. Cycle continues The Mitigation : - Harvested Residue can be "burned" to release stored heat - Burning permanently discharges the Residue (becomes inert "ash") - Cities burn Residue for warmth—creating heated islands - This draws ambient Residue toward population centers (where it's consumed) - Surrounding areas become relatively colder Implications : - Civilization requires Residue burning to survive - Death fuels survival—the fundamental dark irony - Climate can be engineered through Residue management - Battlefields and plague sites are freezing until harvested - Polar regions are extreme because ancient death was never harvested The Five Seasons Year Structure Year Length : 350.667 local days (526 Earth days) Season Breakdown : - Csend (Silence): 76 days - Olvadás (Thaw): 76 days - Láng (Flame): 77 days - Hanyatlás (Decline): 76 days - Köd (Veil): 45.667 days (practically 45-46) - Total : 350.667 days 1. Csend (CHEND) — "The Silence" Position : Aphelion + maximum tilt away (northern hemisphere) Duration : 76 days Character : Deep winter, coldest season Conditions : - Shortest days (as little as 10 hours dim light at high latitudes) - Most extreme cold - Rivers, ports, and seas frozen - Minimal Pattern Residue in atmosphere (Loom less accurate) - Travel only on ice roads - Perfect preservation of dead (Core Binding harvest season) Cultural Associations : Death, endurance, ancestors, debt settlement 2. Olvadás (OL-vah-dahsh) — "The Thaw" Position : Moving toward perihelion Duration : 76 days Character : Early spring, dangerous transition Conditions : - Temperatures rising but unstable - Ice breaking up—flooding, dangerous travel - Pattern Residue rising (concentrated in ice, released in melt) - Narrow planting window - Disease season (frozen pathogens thaw) - Loom accuracy improving Cultural Associations : Rebirth, danger, disease, opportunity, gambling 3. Láng (LAHNG) — "The Flame" Position : Perihelion + maximum tilt toward Duration : 77 days Character : High summer, warmest season Conditions : - Warmest temperatures (relatively—still cold by Earth standards) - Longest days (up to 26 hours light at high latitudes) - Peak Pattern Residue concentration - Loom at maximum accuracy; Warden Order most active - Growing season, trade season, war season - Flesh Shaping most effective (blood doesn't freeze) Cultural Associations : Life, conflict, harvest (crops and cores), fate's height 4. Hanyatlás (HAHN-yaht-lahsh) — "The Decline" Position : Moving toward aphelion Duration : 76 days Character : Late autumn, urgent preparation Conditions : - Temperatures dropping rapidly - Frantic Csend preparation - Second harvest - Pattern Residue beginning to precipitate from atmosphere - Loom accuracy declining - Last chance for outdoor work and travel Cultural Associations : Urgency, harvest, debts coming due, last chances 5. Köd (KUHD) — "The Veil" Position : Aphelion approach, immediately before Csend Duration : 45-46 days (shorter than other seasons) Character : The strange season, Elsewhere bleed Conditions : - Temperatures falling, darkness increasing - Pattern Residue precipitating heavily - The boundary between Hálcova and Elsewhere thins - Effects vary by latitude (see below) The Bleed Gradient : Zone Köd Effects Polar regions Full bleed—Elsewhere entities manifest without summoning High latitudes Partial bleed—entities sensed, partial manifestations, voices Temperate band Minor phenomena—vivid dreams, déjà vu, paranoia Middle Waters Almost nothing—warmth/volcanism/density provides protection Cultural Associations : The unknown, Elsewhere, madness, visions, transformation Geography Continental Structure Five distinct regions across two major continents and three significant landmasses, arranged around the habitable equatorial band. The Five Regions 1. The Greater Continent (The Heartlands) Location : Largest landmass, northern habitable band Geography : - Central mountain spine (east-west, blocks polar winds) - Large interior plateau (cold, harsh, sparse population) - River valleys to coasts (population centers) - Northern edge merges into ice cap Character : - Orthodox faith dominant - Great Loom Node (largest, oldest, most accurate) - Political center—unified governance (empires, kingdoms) - Oldest civilizations, deepest Residue deposits Climate : Subarctic (north) to cold continental (center) to "mild" coastal (south) 2. The Shattered Reaches Location : Fragmented landmass east of the Heartlands Geography : - One large island-continent broken by seas - Many smaller islands in chains and clusters - Rugged coastlines, deep fjords - Sea ice connects islands during Csend Character : - Politically fragmented (city-states, merchant leagues) - Naval power dominant - Trading culture connecting all regions - Religious diversity - Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions Climate : Maritime-moderated, foggier and wetter, shorter ice seasons 3. The Middle Waters Location : Island archipelago in equatorial band (warmest zone) Geography : - Volcanic island chain (geothermal heat) - Central "great island" (dormant supervolcano caldera) - Hundreds of smaller islands - Cold-adapted reef systems Character : - Most valuable real estate (warmth) - Contested by all other regions - Colony traditions strong (warm, wet favors fungal growth) - Unique ecosystem - Cultural melting pot Climate : Warmest on Hálcova (10-20°C in Láng), never freezes 4. The Vent Lands Location : Volcanic continental fragment, southern hemisphere Geography : - Active volcanic ranges - Hot springs, geysers, fumaroles - Geothermal valleys (reliable heat) - Toxic zones (volcanic gas accumulation) - Glacier-thermal interfaces (flooding, steam) Character : - Heat independent of Residue (geothermal) - Wealthy (no fuel dependency) - Politically independent - Unique industries (geothermal metallurgy) - Fleshwright traditions strong - Weaker Orthodox presence Climate : Extreme local variation, steam weather, lush valleys next to frozen peaks 5. The Far Shelf Location : Most distant continent, southern hemisphere Geography : - Large, relatively flat landmass - Extensive tundra and taiga-equivalent - Mineral-rich, difficult extraction - Southern edge touches ice cap - Long coastlines, few harbors Character : - Frontier region (last colonized) - Heterodox faiths dominant - Threadist movements originated here - Hollow Saints more open presence - Less Loom coverage - Independence-minded population Climate : Cold even in Láng, extreme seasonal darkness, shortest growing season The Seas The Narrow Sea : Between Heartlands and Shattered Reaches - Heavily trafficked, partially freezes in Csend - Major trade route, historical naval battles The Central Ocean : Between northern and southern landmasses - Large, dangerous - Liquid center even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Middle Waters in warmest region The Vent Strait : Between Middle Waters and Vent Lands - Warm currents from geothermal activity - Never freezes, dense shipping The Far Water : Between Shattered Reaches and Far Shelf - Widest crossing, most dangerous - Storms, distance, cold The Bitter Crossing : Between Heartlands and Far Shelf (polar route) - Frozen solid in Csend (ice road) - Impassable other seasons - Historical only connection before long-distance sailing Polar Regions The Northern Cap : - Permanent ice sheet - No sustained civilization - Expedition territory only - Rumors of ancient ruins beneath ice - Source of rare materials - Full Elsewhere bleed during Köd The Southern Cap : - Permanent ice sheet - Touches Far Shelf's southern coast - Different character than northern cap (unknown why) - Full Elsewhere bleed during Köd Köd: The Fifth Season in Detail The Polar Bleed During Köd, the boundary between Hálcova and Elsewhere thins. The effect is strongest at the poles and diminishes toward the equator. Full Bleed (Polar Regions) Physical Environment : - Visual distortions (wrong distances, shifted colors) - Sound anomalies (echoes from nothing, unnatural silence) - Temperature fluctuations unconnected to weather - Ground-level aurora-like phenomena Entity Activity : - Elsewhere beings manifest without summoning - Appear partial, flickering, attention wandering - Most ignore humans; some don't - All five factions appear: - Accountants : Counting, ignoring unless debts exist - Hungry : Seeking sensation—the dangerous ones - Architects : Adjusting, positioning, arranging - Mirrors : Watching, following, studying observers - Absent : Simply present, doing nothing visible Human Effects : - Pact Summoners feel entities without calling - Core Binders' echoes become hyperactive, may realize they're dead - Fate Threaders pull "sideways" futures - Colony hosts feel colonies reaching toward something - Unpacted humans: hallucinations, intrusions, compulsions Partial Bleed (Transition Zones) Entities sensed but not fully manifest Voices, glimpses, influences Stronger effects near polar edge Habitable but disturbing Some permanent settlements with adaptation strategies Minor Phenomena (Temperate Band) Vivid dreams, especially of unlived lives Déjà vu and premonition spikes Paranoia and suspicion increase Minor visual/auditory phenomena Loom predictions become strange (accurate about improbable things) Protected Zone (Middle Waters) Minimal Köd effects Theories: warmth, volcanic activity, population density, unknown factor Refugees flee toward Middle Waters during Köd Prices and tensions spike Who Enters the Polar Bleed? The Desperate : Seeking pacts without leverage, escaping patterns, pursuing forbidden knowledge The Fortified : Research expeditions, military operations, resource extraction (heavy protection) The Trapped : Outposts that can't evacuate, indigenous survivors, things that were human Religious Responses Orthodox : Polar bleed proves the danger of straying from The Weaver's design. Wardens close transition borders. Returnees examined for contamination. Threadist : The bleed shows fate is unfinished. Insights from Köd may reveal the collaborative nature of design. Hollow Saint : The bleed is the crack in fate's prison. Pilgrimage to the edge (not into full bleed) is holy work. Colony Cult : Colonies remember something from the bleed. The original unity existed there. Ancestor Speaker : Echoes become dangerous during Köd. This is when the dead most need binding—for their protection. Fleshwright : Elsewhere entities are just different biology. Study them (safely) to understand life without pattern. Pattern Residue Thermodynamics The Mechanism Pattern Residue is "condensed probability"—fate-weight made physical. This exotic matter has unusual thermodynamic properties. Charged State : - Residue in natural/raw form actively absorbs thermal energy - Pulls heat from environment into itself - Stores energy as captured entropy/information Triggered Release : - Specific conditions (chemical, magical, mechanical) release stored energy - Energy emerges as heat - Residue becomes "spent" or "ash"—thermodynamically inert Equilibrium : - Natural Residue absorbs until saturated - Slowly re-radiates over time - Absorption is fast; re-radiation is slow - Net effect: heat trapped, world cooled The Climate Feedback Loop Death releases Pattern Residue Residue absorbs heat from environment Environment cools Cold contributes to death More Residue released Loop continues The Civilization Counter-Loop Residue is harvested Harvested Residue burned for heat Local heat released (cities warm) Spent Residue doesn't return to atmosphere Less atmospheric Residue = slightly warmer baseline But harvesting draws more Residue toward cities Surrounding areas relatively colder Cities become warm islands Implications The Dark Bargain : Civilization survives by burning death. The more death harvested, the warmer cities can be. Peace reduces fuel supply. Climate Control : Institutions could warm or cool regions by managing Residue distribution. This is probably happening. The Polar Question : Why so cold? Ancient mass death? Residue migration? Deliberate engineering? Elsewhere connection? The Middle Waters Question : Why warm? Volcanic heat? Less historical death? Living density? Unknown protection? docs.text: The Mechanism : Pattern Residue in its "charged" state absorbs thermal energy from the environment. It is thermodynamically active—pulling heat into itself. The Feedback Loop : 1. Death releases Pattern Residue 2. Residue absorbs heat from environment 3. Environment cools 4. Cold contributes to more death 5. Cycle continues The Mitigation : - Harvested Residue can be "burned" to release stored heat - Burning permanently discharges the Residue (becomes inert "ash") - Cities burn Residue for warmth—creating heated islands - This draws ambient Residue toward population centers (where it's consumed) - Surrounding areas become relatively colder Implications : - Civilization requires Residue burning to survive - Death fuels survival—the fundamental dark irony - Climate can be engineered through Residue management - Battlefields and plague sites are freezing until harvested - Polar regions are extreme because ancient death was never harvested

The Greater Continent (The Heartlands) Location : Largest landmass, northern habitable band Geography : - Central mountain spine (east-west, blocks polar winds) - Large interior plateau (cold, harsh, sparse population) - River valleys to coasts (population centers) - Northern edge merges into ice cap Character : - Orthodox faith dominant - Great Loom Node (largest, oldest, most accurate) - Political center—unified governance (empires, kingdoms) - Oldest civilizations, deepest Residue deposits Climate : Subarctic (north) to cold continental (center) to "mild" coastal (south) 2. The Shattered Reaches Location : Fragmented landmass east of the Heartlands Geography : - One large island-continent broken by seas - Many smaller islands in chains and clusters - Rugged coastlines, deep fjords - Sea ice connects islands during Csend Character : - Politically fragmented (city-states, merchant leagues) - Naval power dominant - Trading culture connecting all regions - Religious diversity - Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions Climate : Maritime-moderated, foggier and wetter, shorter ice seasons 3. The Middle Waters Location : Island archipelago in equatorial band (warmest zone) Geography : - Volcanic island chain (geothermal heat) - Central "great island" (dormant supervolcano caldera) - Hundreds of smaller islands - Cold-adapted reef systems Character : - Most valuable real estate (warmth) - Contested by all other regions - Colony traditions strong (warm, wet favors fungal growth) - Unique ecosystem - Cultural melting pot Climate : Warmest on Hálcova (10-20°C in Láng), never freezes 4. docs.text: Economics and Class in Hálcova Overview Economics in Hálcova cannot be separated from fate. The Sórscad pattern determines access to credit, employment, insurance, and opportunity. Pattern Residue—the energy of dissolving fates—fuels magic and industry. Death is literally productive. This creates an economy where some people are worth more dead than alive, where peace is expensive, and where the institutions that predict your future have financial stakes in that prediction coming true. The Fate Market Pattern as Asset Your Sórscad is not just identity—it's capital. Pattern-Weight Some patterns are "heavier" than others: - More fate-significance - More likely to impact events - More valuable as Pattern Residue when released Heavy patterns belong to: - Those born into consequential circumstances - Those whose choices ripple outward - Those predicted for significant outcomes (positive or negative) Light patterns belong to: - Those born into marginal circumstances - Those whose choices affect few others - Those predicted for unremarkable outcomes The Market Implications Heavy patterns command higher prices in substitution deals (Pact Summoning) Heavy patterns produce more valuable Residue upon death Heavy patterns are worth more to The Loom (more data value) Heavy patterns are targets for various exploitation This creates a hierarchy: some lives have more market value than others, calculated and priced. Pattern Speculation Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Pattern Arbitrage Some patterns are mispriced. The Loom's predictions, while accurate on average, have errors in individual cases. Arbitrageurs look for: - Patterns undervalued by The Loom (capable people dismissed as low-potential) - Patterns overvalued by The Loom (impressive readings masking actual mediocrity) - Situations where environmental change will shift pattern-outcomes They invest in undervalued people—education, opportunity, resources—and profit when those people outperform predictions. This is legal. It's also morally ambiguous: you're betting on people, treating lives as investments, profiting from the gap between predicted and actual humanity. Credit and Debt Pattern-Based Lending All credit decisions incorporate Sórscad data: Interest Rates Pattern-privileged: Low rates. The Loom predicts they'll repay. Pattern-constrained: High rates. The Loom predicts elevated default risk. Pattern-illegible (practitioners): Variable. Their patterns are too contaminated for reliable prediction. Collateral What can you pledge? Physical assets (traditional) Future earnings (income garnishment) Pattern Residue rights (if you die, the lender harvests) Pact-substitution rights (you can be offered to an Elsewhere entity) Echo-binding rights (you can be bound after death) The last three are where lending gets dark. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. Endpoint possibilities: - Debt-bondage (working off the debt under contract) - Residue-pledge (worth more dead than alive) - Pact-transfer (sold to cover what you owe) - Echo-indenture (bound to serve after death) The system is designed to produce these endpoints. They're not failures of the system—they're the system working as intended. The Pact Economy Elsewhere Entities as Lenders Pact Summoning functions like supernatural credit: - You receive power now - You pay with your core later - Interest accrues (the more you use, the faster you pay) - Default is impossible (the entity always collects) Substitution as Currency Cores are fungible. The entity doesn't care whose core it gets. This creates: - Substitution markets : Where cores are bought and sold - Core brokers : Middlemen connecting those with cores to sell and summoners needing payment - Substitution pricing : Heavy patterns worth more, light patterns worth less - Procurement operations : Acquiring cores through various means (legal and otherwise) The Substitution Hierarchy From most to least valuable: 1. Exceptional patterns (seventh son of seventh son, etc.) 2. Heavy patterns from powerful lineages 3. Standard adult patterns 4. Light adult patterns 5. Child patterns (potential not yet realized) 6. Elderly patterns (mostly spent) 7. Animal patterns (weak, but abundant) This is a price list for souls. It exists. People consult it. Employment and Opportunity Pattern-Gated Careers Many positions require specific pattern profiles: Explicit Requirements - "Must have Court-Field or Heights-Field classification" - "No Wound-Self or Shard-Self candidates" - "Minimum Road-Path or Ladder-Path trajectory" Implicit Screening Even without stated requirements, hiring decisions incorporate pattern data: - "We don't discriminate based on pattern—we just look at the whole candidate" - "Their pattern doesn't fit our company culture" - "The Loom predicts retention issues with that profile" Pattern Families and Stereotypes Certain pattern-combinations are associated with professions: "Lamplighters" (Lantern-Road-Pact-Duty-Court) - Bureaucrats, administrators, reliable employees - Boring but dependable - Automatically considered for stable positions "Storm-Children" (Spark-Crossroads-Twin-Rebel-Wild) - Artists, adventurers, troublemakers - Exciting but unreliable - Automatically excluded from positions requiring stability "Knot-Born" (Wound-Maze-Thorn-Fear-Street) - Criminals, laborers, expendables - Dangerous but useful - Automatically considered for dangerous or demeaning work These stereotypes become self-fulfilling. Denied legitimate opportunity, the Knot-Born turn to illegitimate work. Their criminal records confirm The Loom's predictions. The cycle continues. Labor Markets Pattern Segregation Different patterns concentrate in different industries: - Heights-Field patterns in management - Forge-Field patterns in manufacturing - Street-Field patterns in informal economy - Underbelly-Field patterns in criminal enterprise This isn't natural sorting—it's structural channeling. Each pattern is directed toward "appropriate" work from Binding Day onward. Wage Differentials Same work, different pay, based on pattern: - Pattern-privileged workers paid more (justified as "retention cost") - Pattern-constrained workers paid less (justified as "risk premium") - The gap is legal, documented, defended as actuarially sound The Pattern Residue Economy Production Pattern Residue is produced when patterns dissolve—primarily at death. Natural Production - Every death releases some Residue - More from heavy patterns - More from traumatic deaths - More from pattern-rich populations Sites of Concentration - Battlefields (mass death, often violent) - Plague zones (mass death, weakened patterns) - Execution grounds (controlled, harvestable) - Disaster sites (concentrated mortality) Manufactured Production The demand for Residue creates incentives: - War as industry (mass death with geographic concentration) - Plague management (letting disease run for harvest) - Capital punishment as production (not justice, but fuel) - Blood sports (entertainment plus Residue) The Residue Trade Harvesting Licensed harvesters extract Residue from death sites. Unlicensed harvesters do the same, illegally. Equipment required: - Collection apparatus (varies by tradition) - Storage containers (keeping Residue stable) - Transportation (Residue degrades; speed matters) Occupational hazards: - Exposure effects (too much contact changes you) - Competition (other harvesters, scavengers, authorities) - Moral weight (you're literally profiting from death) Refinement Raw Residue requires processing for most uses: - Purification (removing contaminants) - Stabilization (extending shelf life) - Concentration (increasing potency) - Packaging (making it tradeable) Refineries are industrial operations—factories of death-product. Distribution Residue reaches end users through: - Official channels (licensed trade, taxation, regulation) - Gray markets (legal but questionable sourcing) - Black markets (illegal, untaxed, often higher quality) Pricing Residue prices fluctuate based on: - Supply (peace = scarce; war = abundant) - Quality (pure vs. contaminated) - Source (some deaths produce better Residue) - Demand (more practitioners = higher prices) During prolonged peace, prices spike. Some institutions have incentives to prevent peace from lasting. The Moral Economy Who Benefits From Death The Loom (fuel for operation) Core Binders (fuel for anchors) Residue traders (profit margin) Magitech industries (raw material) Anyone using Residue-powered devices Who Provides Death The pattern-constrained (dying in wars, plagues, prisons) The poor (selling Residue rights for cash now) The condemned (executed for production) Populations deemed "surplus" The economy of Hálcova is built on bodies. Clean hands are expensive. Everyone is complicit at some remove. Class Structure The Pattern-Privileged Characteristics - Born with or drawn into favorable patterns - The Loom predicts success; institutions deliver it - Low interest rates, good jobs, favorable treatment How They Stay Privileged - Marry within pattern-class (maintaining lineage patterns) - Leverage pattern-capital into actual capital - Use wealth to insulate from pattern-deviation consequences - Support institutions that validate pattern-prediction Their Perspective - "The system works—look at my success" - "Pattern-discrimination is just actuarial accuracy" - "If their patterns predicted better, they'd do better" The Pattern-Constrained Characteristics - Born with or drawn into unfavorable patterns - The Loom predicts struggle; institutions ensure it - High interest rates, bad jobs, hostile treatment How They Stay Constrained - Denied opportunity that might disprove predictions - Forced into circumstances that confirm predictions - Accumulate debt, criminal records, health problems - Each confirmation further constrains next generation Their Perspective - "The system is rigged—look at my constraints" - "They decided what I'd be before I could decide anything" - "Success despite pattern proves nothing; they just call it deviation" The Pattern-Illegible Characteristics - Practitioners whose patterns are contaminated, faded, or transformed - The Loom can't predict them reliably - Treated with suspicion, opportunity, or both Types - Heavy Core Binders (layered patterns from echo-bleed) - Established Flesh Shapers (hollowed Húslaimh circles) - Deep Pact Summoners (faded Léilcrù from payment) - Depleted Fate Threaders (narrowed Sórscad from extraction) - Long-term Colony Hosts (hybrid patterns from transformation) Their Position - Some institutions exclude them (can't assess risk) - Some institutions seek them (unpredictability is useful) - They exist outside normal class structure - Often form their own communities and networks The Industrial Magitech Sector Residue-Powered Technology Pattern Residue isn't just for practitioners—it powers industry. Applications - Pattern-engines (The Loom and derivatives) - Communication systems (pattern-resonance transmission) - Transportation (Residue-fueled vehicles for high-priority use) - Manufacturing (certain processes require Residue catalyst) - Weapons (Residue-enhanced ammunition, siege equipment) The Magic-Industrial Complex Industries dependent on Residue form a political bloc: - They need steady supply (war, plague, execution) - They oppose peace when it threatens supply - They support policies that produce harvestable death - They lobby against restrictions on harvesting This isn't conspiracy—it's interest group politics. The people running these industries aren't monsters. They're responding to incentives. The incentives produce monstrous outcomes. Labor in Magitech Working with Residue changes you. Long-term exposure: - Physical effects (pallor, temperature sensitivity, pattern-interference) - Psychological effects (death-awareness, morbid outlook) - Social effects (stigma, isolation from non-exposed) Residue-industry workers are pattern-constrained almost by definition. The work confirms their patterns, trapping them further. The Underground Economy What's Traded Illegally Unregistered cores : Bypassing official harvesting channels Substitution services : Procuring cores for pact-payment Pattern data : Stolen Registry information Unlicensed binding : Echo-services without permits Black-market homunculi : Especially mimics Infection services : Colony hosting outside legal channels Fate-fraud : Forged or manipulated pattern records Deviation assistance : Helping people evade pattern-expectations Criminal Organizations Structure - Often organized by pattern-family (Knot-Born networks, etc.) - Use pattern-illegible members for unpredictable operations - Bribe or coerce Warden Order members - Operate across regions with different enforcement levels Services - Debt elimination (including murdering creditors) - Pattern-laundering (falsifying Registry records) - Protection (from both Wardens and rival organizations) - Procurement (cores, blood, colonies, anything tradeable) Relationship to Legal Economy - Provides services legal economy won't - Employs people legal economy excludes - Operates on same logic (profit, transaction, leverage) - Often partners with "legitimate" institutions quietly The Common Person Daily Economic Life For someone without wealth, special patterns, or practitioner abilities: Employment - Pattern determines options before you apply - Wages set by pattern-class, not just skill - Advancement limited by pattern-ceiling - Termination easy if pattern-excused Credit - High rates if available at all - Collateral requirements often exceed assets - Debt-trap structures common - Pattern-default possible (selling yourself) Housing - Pattern-segregated neighborhoods - Insurance based on district pattern-profile - Mobility limited by pattern-appropriate areas - Quality tracks pattern-privilege Healthcare - Treatment recommendations incorporate pattern-data - "Pattern-appropriate care" means lower quality for constrained - End-of-life decisions consider Residue value - Chronic conditions managed by pattern-expectation Family - Marriage recommendations based on pattern-compatibility - Child-bearing decisions influenced by predicted patterns - Education options constrained by pattern-category - Inheritance affected by pattern-privilege Coping Strategies Acceptance - "My pattern is my pattern" - Find meaning in what fate allows - Orthodox faith provides framework - Community within pattern-class Hustle - Work the system's margins - Find opportunities The Loom undervalues - Build informal networks - Accumulate resources despite predictions Escape - Pattern-illegibility through practice (if you can afford initiation) - Geographical mobility (frontier regions, different enforcement) - Criminal economy (if legitimate economy excludes you) - Pact Summoning (trade pattern for power, lose both eventually) Resistance - Threadist reform movements - Hollow Saint nihilism - Pattern-fraud and deviation - Collective action against pattern-discrimination Most people combine these, shifting between acceptance, hustle, escape attempts, and occasional resistance depending on circumstances. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. Endpoint possibilities: - Debt-bondage (working off the debt under contract) - Residue-pledge (worth more dead than alive) - Pact-transfer (sold to cover what you owe) - Echo-indenture (bound to serve after death) The system is designed to produce these endpoints. They're not failures of the system—they're the system working as intended.
